facts.text: Petition No. 172 of 1956 filed in Original Jurisdiction under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of Habeas Corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 172 of 1956. Under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of Habeas Corpus. N. Andely, amicus curiae, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner was under detention by virtue of an order dated 5th September 1956 issued by Government of Jammu and Kashmir under sub-section 2 of section 3 taken with sub-section 1 of section 12 of Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act 2011.

anchor.surface_text: This is an application under article 32 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ in the nature of habeas companypus against the State of, Jammu and Kashmir by the petitioner who was under detention by virtue of an order dated the 5th September, 1956, issued by the Government of the State of Jammu and Kashmir under sub-section  2  of sec- tion 3 taken with sub-section  1  of section 12 of Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 2011  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Petitioner was first placed under detention by order passed by District Magistrate Jammu under subsection 2 of section 3 of the Act on 1st May 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was first placed under detention by virtue of an order passed by the District Magistrate, Jammu, under subsection  2  of section 3 of the Act on the 1st May, 1956, and that order was companyfirmed and companytinued on the 5th September, 1956, under sub-section  1  of section 12 of the Act by the Government after taking the opinion of the Advisory Board.

facts.text: First detention order confirmed and continued on 5th September 1956 by Government after taking opinion of Advisory Board.

anchor.surface_text: and that order was companyfirmed and companytinued on the 5th September, 1956, under sub-section  1  of section 12 of the Act by the Government after taking the opinion of the Advisory Board. The two orders of detention, one of the District Magistrate dated the 1st May, 1956, and the other of the Government dated the 5th September, 1956, recited that the petitioner is directed to be detained because it was, necessary to make such an order with a view to preventing him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity.

facts.text: Grounds of detention communicated to petitioner on 31st May 1956 by District Magistrate Jammu.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention as companymunicated to the petitioner on the 31st May, 1956, by the District Magistrate, Jammu, are as -follows That you carried on smuggling of essential goods to Pakistan through the Ferozpur and Amritsar border, but since the tightening of said borders you have recently shifted your smuggling activities to Ranbirsinghpura Pakistan borders in the State of Jammu and Kashmir and are carrying on illicit smuggling of essential goods such as cloth, zari and mercury to Pakistan through this border  thus affecting the economic companydition of the public in Kashmir State adversely .

facts.text: Petitioner carried on smuggling of essential goods to Pakistan through Ferozpur and Amritsar border, then shifted to Ranbirsinghpura Pakistan borders in Jammu and Kashmir.

anchor.surface_text: That you carried on smuggling of essential goods to Pakistan through the Ferozpur and Amritsar border, but since the tightening of said borders you have recently shifted your smuggling activities to Ranbirsinghpura Pakistan borders in the State of Jammu and Kashmir and are carrying on illicit smuggling of essential goods such as cloth, zari and mercury to Pakistan through this border  thus affecting the economic companydition of the public in Kashmir State adversely .

facts.text: Petitioner smuggling illicit essential goods such as cloth, zari and mercury to Pakistan through Ranbirsinghpura border, affecting economic condition of public in Kashmir State adversely.

anchor.surface_text: That you carried on smuggling of essential goods to Pakistan through the Ferozpur and Amritsar border, but since the tightening of said borders you have recently shifted your smuggling activities to Ranbirsinghpura Pakistan borders in the State of Jammu and Kashmir and are carrying on illicit smuggling of essential goods such as cloth, zari and mercury to Pakistan through this border  thus affecting the economic companydition of the public in Kashmir State adversely .

facts.text: Petitioner went to village Darsoopura on 7th April 1956 and contacted Ghulam Ahmed son of Suraj bin resident of Darsoopura Tehsil Ranbirsinghpura and Ram Lal son of Frangi resident of Miran Sahib Tehsil Ranbirsinghpura for smuggling.

anchor.surface_text: That for the said purpose of smuggling of goods to Pakistan you went to village Darsoopura on 7th April, 1956, and companytacted Ghulam Ahmed son of Suraj bin resident of Darsoopura Tehsil Ranbirsinghpura and one Ram Lal son of Frangi resident of Miran Sahib Tehsil Ranbirsinghpura and others who I similarly are addicted to carrying on such a smuggling business and with their aid made arrangements for export of Shaffon cloth worth Rs. 2,500 to Pakistan through Ranbirsinghpura Pakistan border.

facts.text: Arrangements made for export of Shaffon cloth worth Rs. 2500 to Pakistan through Ranbirsinghpura border with aid of Ghulam Ahmed and Ram Lal.

anchor.surface_text: and with their aid made arrangements for export of Shaffon cloth worth Rs. 2,500 to Pakistan through Ranbirsinghpura Pakistan border. That on 11-4-1956, you booked 3 bales of silk cloth through Messrs Jaigopal Rajkumar Shegal of Amritsar to Jammu Tawi and got these bales on address of yourself, and on the same day you got one package of Tila booked through S. Kanti Lal Zarianwalla of Amritsar and got this package also addressed To self for Jammu Tawi.

facts.text: On 11-4-1956, petitioner booked 3 bales of silk cloth through Messrs Jaigopal Rajkumar Shegal of Amritsar to Jammu Tawi addressed to self.

anchor.surface_text: That on 11-4-1956, you booked 3 bales of silk cloth through Messrs Jaigopal Rajkumar Shegal of Amritsar to Jammu Tawi and got these bales on address of yourself, and on the same day you got one package of Tila booked through S. Kanti Lal Zarianwalla of Amritsar and got this package also addressed To self for Jammu Tawi. That after booking these packages as aforesaid you came over to Jammu and waited for their arrival and companytacted Ghulam Ahmed and Ram Lal the above mentioned persons.

facts.text: On 11-4-1956, petitioner booked one package of Tila through S. Kanti Lal Zarianwalla of Amritsar addressed to self for Jammu Tawi.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day you got one package of Tila booked through S. Kanti Lal Zarianwalla of Amritsar and got this package also addressed To self for Jammu Tawi. That after booking these packages as aforesaid you came over to Jammu and waited for their arrival and companytacted Ghulam Ahmed and Ram Lal the above mentioned persons.

facts.text: Petitioner came to Jammu after booking packages, waited for arrival, contacted Ghulam Ahmed and Ram Lal.

anchor.surface_text: That after booking these packages as aforesaid you came over to Jammu and waited for their arrival and companytacted Ghulam Ahmed and Ram Lal the above mentioned persons. That on the 15th April, 1956, you tried to get the transport receipt from the Punjab National. Bank but did number succeed in doing so as it was a public holiday.

facts.text: On 15th April 1956, petitioner tried to get transport receipt from Punjab National Bank but failed as public holiday.

anchor.surface_text: That on the 15th April, 1956, you tried to get the transport receipt from the Punjab National. Bank but did number succeed in doing so as it was a public holiday. Meanwhile your activities leaked out and the goods were seized by the Central Customs and Excise Department of India.

facts.text: Goods seized by Central Customs and Excise Department of India after activities leaked out.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile your activities leaked out and the goods were seized by the Central Customs and Excise Department of India. There are other facts also but those cannot be given as I companysider their disclosure would be against the public interest.

facts.text: High Court of Jammu and Kashmir delivered judgment dated 21st June 1956 on petitioner's application and others.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Jammu and Kashmir, to whom a similar application was filed by this petitioner along with a number of others similarly detained for illicit smuggling of goods, has in its judgment dated the 21st June, 1956 held that Shaffon cloth is number within the category of an essential companymodity as defined in the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Ordinance of Jammu and Kashmir.

facts.text: High Court held Shaffon cloth not an essential commodity under Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Ordinance of Jammu and Kashmir.

anchor.surface_text: has in its judgment dated the 21st June, 1956 held that Shaffon cloth is number within the category of an essential companymodity as defined in the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Ordinance of Jammu and Kashmir. There is numberindication in the High Court judgment whether zari is or is number an essential companymodity in the same sense.

facts.text: Porus Mehta stated on instructions that zari is not an essential commodity under the Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: But in answer to a query from this Court, Shri Porus Mehta who appeared before us on behalf of the State of Jammu and Kashmir has stated, on instructions, that zari which is obviously a luxury article is number one of the companymodities declared essential under the above Ordinance.

facts.text: High Court upheld detention of petitioner because mercury is an essential commodity per Ordinance definition.

anchor.surface_text: The case of Dwarika Das Bhatia stands on s different footing altogether. The allegation against him is that he smuggled into Pakistan some goods such as cloth and zari along with a certain quantity of mercury. Mercury is a number-ferrous metal and according to the definition of an essential companymodity given in the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Ordinance, mercury is an essential companymodity. This being so, Dwarika Das Bhatias detention cannot be challenged.

facts.text: Supreme Court quashed the detention order as invalid because based on smuggling of cloth, zari (not essential) and mercury (essential), with no material that smuggling was substantially only mercury.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed.

facts.text: Particulars in grounds relate only to cloth and zari, indicating smuggling of these not inconsequential.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand the fact that the particulars furnished to the detenue on the 31st May, 1956, relate only to cloth and zari  we understand that tila referred to in paragraph 3 is zari  indicates that probably the smuggling of these two items was number of an inconsequential nature.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 1, 1956 by JAGANNADHADAS J.

anchor.surface_text: 1956. November 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J.-This is an application under article 32 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ in the nature of habeas companypus against the State of, Jammu and Kashmir by the petitioner who was under detention by virtue of an order dated the 5th September, 1956,

facts.text: Detention orders recited necessity to prevent petitioner acting prejudicial to maintenance of supplies and services essential to community.

anchor.surface_text: The two orders of detention, one of the District Magistrate dated the 1st May, 1956, and the other of the Government dated the 5th September, 1956, recited that the petitioner is directed to be detained because it was, necessary to make such an order with a view to preventing him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity.

anchor.surface_text: The point raised before us is that since the detention is based on the assumption that Shaffon cloth and zari as well as mercury are all essential goods and since two out of the three categories of the goods with reference to the smuggling of which the detention has been directed, are found number to be essential goods, the entire order is illegal, although one of the items, viz., mercury is an essential companymodity. In support of this contention, the cases of this Court in Dr. Ram Krishan Bhardwaj v. The,, State of Delhi 1 , and Shibban Lal Saksena v. The State of P.  2  are relied upon.

But in answer to a query from this Court, Shri Porus Mehta who appeared before us on behalf of the State of Jammu and Kashmir has stated, on instructions, that zari which is obviously a luxury article is number one of the companymodities declared essential under the above Ordinance.

issues.text: whether an order of detention is invalid if the grounds supplied in support thereof are vague, and whether the vagueness of one or some of the various grounds vitiates the entire order

anchor.surface_text: In Dr. Ram Krishan Bhardwajs case  supra  the two points that were raised were  1  whether an order of detention is invalid if the grounds supplied in support thereof are vague, and  2  whether the vagueness of one or some of the various grounds vitiates the entire order.

[...] The question before the companyrt was whether this companyfirmation of the original order of detention, when one of the two grounds was found to be number-existent by the Advisory Board, companyld be maintained.

anchor.surface_text: Posing the situation which arises in such cases where one of the grounds is found to be irrelevant or unsubstantiated, the Court stated as follows The question is, whether in such circumstances the original order made under section 3 1   a  of the Act can be allowed to stand.

arguments.claim: Dwarika Das Bhatia's detention cannot be challenged because mercury is an essential commodity under the definition in the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: The case of Dwarika Das Bhatia stands on s different footing altogether. The allegation against him is that he smuggled into Pakistan some goods such as cloth and zari along with a certain quantity of mercury. Mercury is a non-ferrous metal and according to the definition of an essential commodity given in the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Ordinance, mercury is an essential commodity. This being so, Dwarika Das Bhatias detention cannot be challenged.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: because the matter being one for subjec- tive satisfaction, it must be properly based. on all the reasons on which it purports to be based. If some ,o

arguments.court_reasoning: Invalid grounds (smuggling non-essential cloth and zari) vitiate entire order as court cannot sever impact on subjective satisfaction; smuggling of non-essentials not inconsequential.

arguments.claim: Since the detention is based on the assumption that Shaffon cloth, zari and mercury are all essential goods but two out of three are not essential, the entire order is illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The point raised before us is that since the detention is based on the assumption that Shaffon cloth and zari as well as mercury are all essential goods and since two out of the three categories of the goods with reference to the smuggling of which the detention has been directed, are found not to be essential goods, the entire order is illegal, although one of the items, viz., mercury is an essential commodity.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: because the matter being one for subjec- tive satisfaction, it must be properly based. on all the reasons on which it purports to be based. If some ,o

arguments.court_reasoning: Precedents apply by analogy to irrelevant grounds; no material smuggling substantially only mercury; particulars emphasize cloth/zari.

arguments.claim: The principle of Dr. Ram Krishan Bhardwaj and Shibban Lal Saksena has no application to the present case.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the State of Jammu and Kashmir contends that the principle of these decisions has no application to the present case, and attempts to distinguish the same.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: The sufficiency Of the grounds upon which such satisfaction purports to be based, provided they have a rational probative value and are number extrane

arguments.court_reasoning: Court examines precedents in detail and applies principles to irrelevant (non-essential goods) grounds as analogous to vague/non-existent grounds.

arguments.claim: The order of detention is bad and must be quashed as no material shows smuggling was substantially only mercury and particulars indicate cloth/zari smuggling not inconsequential.

anchor.surface_text: No material is placed before us enabling us to say that the smuggling attributed to the petitioner was substantially only of mercury and that the smuggling as regards the other two commodities was of an inconsequential nature. On the other hand the fact that the particulars furnished to the detenue on the 31st May, 1956, relate only to cloth and zari... We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed.

holdings.text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the order of detention in this case is bad and must be quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detention based on smuggling of cloth, zari (non-essential) and mercury (essential); invalid grounds vitiate entire order as per precedents since no material shows non-essential smuggling inconsequential and court cannot substitute objective test for subjective satisfaction.

holdings.text: No material is placed before us enabling us to say that the smuggling attributed to the petitioner was substantially only of mercury and that the smuggling as regards the other two commodities was of an inconsequential nature.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand the fact that the particulars furnished to the detenue on the 31st May, 1956, relate only to cloth and zari  we understand that tila referred to in paragraph 3 is zari  indicates that probably the smuggling of these two items was number of an inconsequential nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of evidence on proportions of smuggling; grounds' particulars emphasize cloth and zari.

holdings.text: the fact that the particulars furnished to the detenue on the 31st May, 1956, relate only to cloth and zari ... indicates that probably the smuggling of these two items was not of an inconsequential nature.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand the fact that the particulars furnished to the detenue on the 31st May, 1956, relate only to cloth and zari  we understand that tila referred to in paragraph 3 is zari  indicates that probably the smuggling of these two items was number of an inconsequential nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Content of communicated grounds focuses solely on non-essential goods smuggling activities.

holdings.text: This principle ... seems to us to be quite sound and applicable to the facts of this case.

anchor.surface_text: In such cases, we think, the position would be the same as if one of these two grounds was irrelevant for the purpose of the Act or was wholly illusory and this would vitiate the detention order as a whole. This principle, which was recognised by the Federal Court in the case of Keshav Talpade v. The King Emperor 1 , seems to us to be quite sound and applicable to the facts of this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Approves and applies precedents equating irrelevant grounds to vague/non-existent ones vitiating detention.

holdings.text: In applying these principles, however, the Court must be satisfied that the vague or irrelevant grounds are such as if excluded, might reasonably have affected the subjective satisfaction of the appropriate authority. It is not merely because some ground or reason of a comparatively unessential nature is defective that such an order based on subjective satisfaction can be held to be invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In applying these principles, however, the Court must be satisfied that the vague or irrelevant grounds are such as-, if excluded, might reasonably have affected the subjective satisfaction of the appropriate authority. It is number merely because some ground or reason of a companyparatively unessential nature is defective that such an order based on subjective satisfaction can be held to be invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Qualifying test from Keshav Talpade for when partial invalidity vitiates order: invalid grounds must be potentially material to satisfaction.

holdings.text: zari which is obviously a luxury article is not one of the commodities declared essential under the above Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: But in answer to a query from this Court, Shri Porus Mehta who appeared before us on behalf of the State of Jammu and Kashmir has stated, on instructions, that zari which is obviously a luxury article is number one of the companymodities declared essential under the above Ordinance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acceptance of respondent's concession on instructions in response to court's query.

precedents.case_name: Dr Ram Krishan Bhardwaj v State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: vagueness of one or some of the various grounds vitiates the entire order of detention if constitutional safeguard not satisfied for each ground
precedents.cited_holding: constitutional requirement must be satisfied with respect to each of the grounds communicated to the person detained... That not having been done... detention cannot be held to be in accordance with the procedure established by law

precedents.citation: Shibban Lal Saksena v. The State of P.  2

anchor.surface_text: , and Shibban Lal Saksena v. The State of P.  2  are relied upon. Learned companynsel for the State of Jammu and Kashmir companytends that the principle of these decisions

precedents.case_name: Shibban Lal Saksena v State of UP
precedents.cited_proposition: if one of the grounds of detention is irrelevant or unsubstantiated, the detention order cannot stand as the court cannot assess the extent each ground contributed to subjective satisfaction
precedents.cited_holding: the position would be the same as if one of these two grounds was irrelevant for the purpose of the Act or was wholly illusory and this would vitiate the detention order as a whole

anchor.surface_text: the view adopted by this Court in the decision in Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidyas case 3 , viz., that the obligation cast on the detaining authority to supply grounds is for the purpose

precedents.case_name: Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya v State
precedents.cited_proposition: obligation to supply grounds to detenue is to enable making a fair representation against detention order

precedents.citation: Keshav Talpade v. The King Emperor 1

anchor.surface_text: This principle, which was recognised by the Federal Court in the case of Keshav Talpade v. The King Emperor 1 , seems to us to be quite sound and applicable to the facts of this case.

precedents.cited_proposition: if detaining authority gives multiple reasons and some are bad, cannot be certain to what extent bad reasons operated on the mind or if order would have been made without them
precedents.cited_holding: it can never be certain to what extent the bad reasons operated on the mind of the authority or whether the detention order would have been made at all if only one or two good reasons had been before them

The quashing of the detention order in the holding is grounded in the proper application and interpretation of the Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 2011.

In such cases, we think, the position would be the same as if one of these two grounds was irrelevant for the purpose of the Act or was wholly illusory and this would vitiate the detention order as a whole. This principle, which was recognised by the Federal Court in the case of Keshav Talpade v. The King Emperor 1 , seems to us to be quite sound and applicable to the facts of this case.
